description: From Old French divorce, from Latin dīvortium, from dīvertere (“to turn aside”), from dī- (“apart”) + vertere (“to turn”); see verse.

entries.meaning: The legal dissolution of a marriage.
examples: Richard obtained a divorce from his wife some years ago, but hasn't returned to the dating scene.
The Civil War split between Virginia and West Virginia was a divorce based along cultural and economic as well as geographic lines.

entries.meaning: (zoology) The separation of a bonded pair of animals.

verbs.description: divorce (third-person singular simple present divorces, present participle divorcing, simple past and past participle divorced)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To legally dissolve a marriage between two people.
examples: A ship captain can marry couples, but cannot divorce them.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To end one's own marriage to (a person) in this way.
examples: Lucy divorced Steve when she discovered that he had been unfaithful.
Edna and Simon divorced last year; he got the house, and she retained the business.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To separate something that was connected.
examples: The radical group voted to divorce itself from the main faction and start an independent movement.
